error.signature: Error response from daemon: manifest for image not found
error.regex: manifest.*not found|image.*not found|pull access denied|repository does not exist

verdict.summary: Docker image or tag does not exist in the registry. Could be a typo, wrong tag, private registry auth issue, or architecture mismatch.

dead_ends.action: Repeatedly retrying docker pull without checking the image name
dead_ends.why_fails: If the image or tag doesn't exist, retries will always fail

workarounds.action: Verify image name and tag are correct â€” check for typos
workarounds.how:
docker search <image_name>
# Verify the exact image name on Docker Hub or your registry.
# Common mistakes: 'postgress' vs 'postgres', 'node:18-alpine' vs 'node:18-Alpine'

workarounds.action: For private images, authenticate to the registry before pull
workarounds.how:
# Docker Hub:
docker login -u <username>

# Private registry:
docker login registry.example.com

# AWS ECR:
aws ecr get-login-password | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin <account>.dkr.ecr.<region>.amazonaws.com

# GCR:
gcloud auth configure-docker

workarounds.action: Check available tags and architectures on the registry
workarounds.how:
# List available tags for a Docker Hub image:
curl -s 'https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/library/node/tags/?page_size=20' | jq '.results[].name'

# Check if the tag supports your architecture:
docker manifest inspect --verbose node:18-alpine | jq '.[].Platform'

# For multi-arch builds, use --platform:
docker pull --platform linux/amd64 node:18-alpine

frequently_confused_with.distinction: image-not-found means the repository or tag doesn't exist; manifest-unknown typically means the specific tag is missing from an existing repository.
